abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The Oriental fruit fly <jats:italic>Bactrocera dorsalis</jats:italic> (Hendel), a global pest that can decimate regional fruit industries and elicit international quarantines, has been the subject of considerable taxonomic confusion. Previous phylogenetic work revealed that <jats:italic>B. dorsalis</jats:italic> is part of a monophyletic clade containing 12 species. We present restriction site‐associated DNA sequencing (RAD‐seq) genomic data for 2,292 specimens, which unequivocally supports the delimitation of two new species, here described as <jats:italic>Bactrocera borneoensis</jats:italic> <jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold> Doorenweerd & San Jose and <jats:italic>B. incognita</jats:italic> <jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold> Doorenweerd & San Jose. We additionally obtained 1,985 Cytochrome C oxidase I (COI) sequences for a subset of the specimens to see which species can be diagnosed with this mtDNA marker and conclude that <jats:italic>B. dorsalis</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>B. incognita</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>B. carambolae</jats:italic> Drew & Hancock, <jats:italic>B. raiensis</jats:italic> Drew & Hancock, <jats:italic>B. occipitalis</jats:italic> (Bezzi) and <jats:italic>B. kandiensis</jats:italic> Drew & Hancock cannot be identified reliably using COI due to introgression—but the newly described species <jats:italic>B. borneoensis</jats:italic> can be identified using COI. The supposed innocuous species <jats:italic>B. raiensis</jats:italic> distribution is underestimated in Asia and Africa. <jats:italic>Bactrocera kandiensis</jats:italic> COI genotypes occur in African flies, but RAD‐seq data confirm that these are <jats:italic>B. dorsalis</jats:italic> with introgressed <jats:italic>B. kandiensis</jats:italic> COI. The phylogenomic dataset brings new light to the extent of the <jats:italic>B. dorsalis s.l.</jats:italic> clade and the morphological and molecular confusion based on COI. This will have ramifications for ecological data—including host and distribution ranges—associated with <jats:italic>B. dorsalis s.l.</jats:italic> clade species, pest identification protocols and our understanding of the economic importance of the various species in the clade.</jats:p>
title: Genomic data reveal new species and the limits of <scp>mtDNA</scp> barcode diagnostics to contain a global pest species complex (<scp>Diptera: Tephritidae: Dacinae</scp>)
